author: By Matt Phillips
title: Market Edges Toward Euphoria, Despite Pandemic’s Toll
description: Investors of all stripes piled into stocks this year, creating levels of froth reminiscent of the dot-com boom. Analysts say there’s room to go higher, but some worry about a bubble.
content: The stock market will not quit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Snail, Fish and Sheep Soup, Anyone? Savory New Finds at Pompeii
description: The ancient site is the archaeological gift that keeps on giving. A food shop excavated this month suggests that its ancient residents had singular culinary tastes.
content: ROME — Wine turned white with crushed fava beans. A soupy concoction of snails, sheep and fish.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Crouse
title: She Turned 2020 Misery Into a Breakthrough
description: Sara Hall is a 37-year-old elite marathoner and mother of four. She showed me how years of setbacks can lead to unexpected rewards.
content: Just a few months ago, the veteran American distance runner Sara Hall seemed to be facing her own version of pandemic misery. She had failed to qualify for the Olympics, dropping out of her last two marathons. Now everything was canceled and she was caring for four daughters at home. She was 37, an age when many elite athletes’ careers start winding down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Cowell
title: The Brexit Fight, Through a Reporter’s Prism of a Changed Continent
description: Alan Cowell, a longtime New York Times correspondent, recalls a different Europe, one of currency controls, cumbersome paperwork and burdensome cross-border regulations.
content: LONDON — An image from my sepia-toned memory in the 1950s: by a summery wheat field freckled with poppies in northern France, English vacationers have halted for tea. A man primes a hand-cranked paraffin stove. A battered kettle is produced, and a teapot. Driving by in their bouncy Citroën 2CVs and curvy Renault Dauphines, French motorists observe the ritual with tolerant bemusement or haughty disdain. British travelers, a rarity then, wave when they spot a kindred license plate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Dooley, Raphael Minder, Marc Santora, Isabella Kwai and Norimitsu Onishi
title: Japan, Spain, France, Sweden and Canada find cases of the new coronavirus variant.
description: The discovery of the U.K. variant has prompted more travel restrictions.
content: Japan, Spain, France, Sweden and Canada have found small numbers of infections involving a new, potentially more transmissible variant of the coronavirus, most linked to travel from the U.K., where it was first detected.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: It’s lonely on the top, and in the lodge, as ski resorts struggle.
description: A trickle of skiers recently zigzagged down the slopes at the Squaw Valley Ski Resort. Couples and families wandered through the resort’s village, which was decorated with golden Christmas lights and frosted with snow.
content: A trickle of skiers recently zigzagged down the slopes at the Squaw Valley Ski Resort. Couples and families wandered through the resort’s village, which was decorated with golden Christmas lights and frosted with snow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Caramanica
title: John Fletcher, a.k.a. Ecstasy of the Group Whodini, Dies at 56
description: He was, the executive who signed Whodini said, “truly one of the first rap stars” and a sex symbol “when they were very scarce in the early days of rap.”
content: John Fletcher, who as Ecstasy of the foundational hip-hop group Whodini was the engine for some of the genre’s first pop successes, wearing a flamboyant Zorroesque hat all the while, died on Wednesday.  He was 56.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Our 50 Most Popular Vegetarian Recipes of 2020
description: Save and cook them all.
content: Save and cook our most popular vegetarian recipes of the year: Colu Henry’s roasted tomato and white bean stew (above); Yasmin Fahr’s sheet-pan baked feta with broccolini, tomatoes and lemon; Yewande Komolafe’s crispy tofu with cashews and blistered snap peas; Alison Roman’s spicy white bean stew with broccoli rabe; and many more in the collection below. (And don’t miss our roundups of all our most popular recipes and desserts.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: Sailors Stranded for Months as China Refuses to Let Ships Unload Australian Coal
description: China is vague about why vessels that carried Australian coal to its ports can’t unload their cargo. “We’re all depressed; our mental health is deteriorating,” one sailor said.
content: MELBOURNE, Australia — For the past six months, Virendrasinh Bhosale, a seafarer from India, has been trapped on a hunk of metal floating off China’s eastern coast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Rutenberg, Nick Corasaniti and Alan Feuer
title: Trump’s Fraud Claims Died in Court, But the Myth of Stolen Elections Lives On
description: For years, Republicans have used the specter of cheating as a reason to impose barriers to ballot access. A definitive debunking of claims of wrongdoing in 2020 has not changed that message.
content: President Trump’s baseless and desperate claims of a stolen election over the last seven weeks — the most aggressive promotion of “voter fraud” in American history — failed to get any traction in courts across seven states, or come anywhere close to reversing the loss he suffered to Joseph R. Biden Jr.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Cohen
title: A ‘Great Cultural Depression’ Looms for Legions of Unemployed Performers
description: With theaters and concert halls shuttered, unemployment in the arts has cut deeper than in restaurants and other hard-hit industries.
content: In the top echelons of classical music, the violinist Jennifer Koh is by any measure a star.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Truck Jam Eases at U.K. Port Days After France Reopens Border
description: Even with new restrictions around the world to try to stop the transmission of a virus variant sweeping rapidly across Britain, the mutation has already spread to France, Spain and Japan.
content: LONDON — A huge truck jam at the Port of Dover in England eased further on Saturday, days after France lifted a border blockade imposed over fears of a fast-spreading variant of the coronavirus that has already been transmitted to continental Europe and Japan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eve Lyons and Elizabeth Bristow
title: Photography From the Year Time Stopped
description: Remember when? You probably don’t.
content: Usually, a photograph captures a moment in time and space. But this year, time and space were slippery and elastic. In the United States, things started off normally enough. January and February were sharply in focus: 2020 vision. But by March, time and space took on new implications and contexts. Time was counted in lockdown days; space, measured in increments of a safe six feet apart.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas, Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs, Giulia McDonnell Nieto del Rio and Steve Cavendish
title: Federal Agents Scour Home as They Hunt for Clues in Nashville Blast
description: Investigators said they were working to determine whether more than one person was involved in the Christmas Day explosion that rattled the city.
content: NASHVILLE — Investigators were rushing on Saturday to piece together what officials described as an elaborate jigsaw puzzle, chasing hundreds of leads, to identify the culprit and the motivation behind the Christmas Day explosion that rocked Nashville.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Will Pandemic End My Career, Performers Ask
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, December 26, 2020.
content: “My fear is we’re not just losing jobs, we’re losing careers.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nagourney
title: A Stinging Setback in California Is a Warning for Democrats in 2022
description: Democrats lost four swing House districts in the state, suggesting that their hold on a number of formerly Republican seats is tenuous at best.
content: LOS ANGELES — Two years ago, Democrats celebrated a sweep of seven Republican-held congressional seats in California as evidence of the party’s growing ability to compete in swing districts here and across the nation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheri Fink
title: As Virus Resurges in Africa, Doctors Fear the Worst Is Yet to Come
description: The coronavirus killed far fewer people in Africa than in Europe and the Americas, leading to a widespread perception that it was a disease of the West. Now, a tide of new cases on the continent is raising alarms.
content: PORT ELIZABETH, South Africa — At the center of a terrifying coronavirus surge, 242 patients lay in row after row of beds under the soaring metal beams of a decommissioned Volkswagen factory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Cryptic Crossword
description: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon work on their off week to send us into 2021.
content: CRYPTIC CROSSWORD — The cryptic is the crossword for the Sisyphus in all of us. Every time I finish a tough one, I feel as if I’ve made progress — so why is the next one never any easier? This is not a lament, let alone a complaint, yet it bears mentioning in case anyone else feels the same. Cryptics are always so much fun, though, and it is true that practice makes for a better solve, and a higher level of appreciation for cryptic “setters” or constructors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: The truck jam at a U.K. port is easing, days after France reopened its border.
description: A huge truck jam at the Port of Dover in England eased further on Saturday, days after France lifted a border blockade imposed over fears of a fast-spreading variant of the coronavirus.
content: A huge truck jam at the Port of Dover in England eased further on Saturday, days after France lifted a border blockade imposed over fears of a fast-spreading variant of the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryan Pietsch
title: Ruling on Woman on Death Row Puts Her Execution in Doubt
description: A new delay could push Lisa Montgomery’s execution into the administration of President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr., who has said he opposes the death penalty.
content: A ruling by a federal judge to delay the execution of the only woman on federal death row could push the new date into the early days of the administration of President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr., who has said he would work to end federal capital punishment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: The Warriors’ Championship Glow Is Gone. And Yet …
description: Yes, the Golden State Warriors have looked awful in two blowout losses to start the season. But there are a few reasons for optimism. One big one: James Wiseman.
content: Before traveling to Milwaukee for their game against the Bucks on Friday afternoon, the Golden State Warriors spent four nights in New York.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The International Herald Tribune
title: 1895: Wretched Weather Mars Christmas in London
description: Rain, snow and driving sleet hit the British capital 125 years ago, though a program offering poor children a hamper of holiday foods was a bright spot.
content: [BY THE HERALD’S SPECIAL WIRE.] LONDON, Dec. 26. — At the best, London is a dull and desolate city in which to spend Christmas Day, but yesterday the weather was successful in giving the town a specially wretched appearance. The streets, after the heavy rain which had fallen through the night, were wet and muddy, and rain, snow and driving sleet fell at intervals during the entire day and kept the streets clearer of foot passengers than on an ordinary Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: The E.U.’s vaccinations are set to begin Sunday, but a few places have jumped the gun.
description: The full rollout of the European Union’s vast vaccine campaign begins Sunday.
content: A 101-year-old woman in a nursing home in eastern Germany became the country’s first recipient of the BioNTech-Pfizer vaccine on Saturday, a day ahead of the European Union’s planned immunization campaign, an ambitious effort to eventually inoculate more than 450 million people across the 27 nations in the European Union against the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon Otterman
title: Why 530 Frozen Bodies Sit in a Brooklyn Warehouse
description: In the first wave of Covid, the crush of bodies overwhelmed New York City’s capacity to deal with the dead. Now, the city is prepared if a second onslaught occurs.
content: At the marine terminal in South Brooklyn this month, a sign that said “funeral director” pointed to the left of a vast warehouse just past the guard gate. A row of 53-foot refrigerated trailers, about 20 in all, sat in the black-tarred parking lot. Tucked past the fashionable furniture warehouses of Industry City and next to a crumbling pier building, the facility was quiet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah Engel Bromwich
title: The Darkest Timeline
description: “Deep Adaptation” made people confront the end of the world from climate change. Does it matter if it’s not correct?
content: Two years ago, an influential paper suggested that we were too late to save the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: A Beloved World War II Photo Comes to Life in a Virtual Reunion
description: Martin Adler, now 96, was looking for German troops in 1944 when he almost shot three Italian children. His daughter’s internet appeal brought them all together again this month.
content: ROME — Martin Adler was a 20-year-old private first class in the 339th Infantry regiment in 1944 when he and a fellow soldier went door to door in an Italian town looking for German troops.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ernesto Londoño
title: Brazil Is Famous for Its Meat. But Vegetarianism Is Soaring.
description: The number of vegetarians in Brazil doubled over a six-year period, which has given rise to a booming plant-based industry that is seeking to turn meatpacking plants obsolete.
content: RIO DE JANEIRO — After years of whipping up large vegan meals for an ashram in the mountains outside Rio de Janeiro, Luiza de Marilac Tavares found her life upended, and herself out of a job, when the pandemic forced the center to shut down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy and Adam Rasgon
title: Austria enters its third lockdown. Israel is set to follow suit.
description: Austria entered a third lockdown on Saturday, with all nonessential shops and schools to remain closed for three weeks and movement to be restricted, after the country eased restrictions in mid-December to allow for preparations ahead of the Christmas holiday.
content: Austria entered a third lockdown on Saturday, with all nonessential shops and schools to remain closed for three weeks and movement to be restricted, after the country eased restrictions in mid-December to allow for preparations ahead of the Christmas holiday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Levin
title: A Racial Slur, a Viral Video, and a Reckoning
description: A white high school student withdrew from her chosen college after a three-second video caused an uproar online. The classmate who shared it publicly has no regrets.
content: [To read more stories on race from The New York Times, sign up here for our Race/Related newsletter.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Alvin Kamara Runs for Six Touchdowns Against Vikings
description: The Saints running back tied an N.F.L. record set in 1929 in New Orleans’ 52-33 win over the Minnesota Vikings.
content: NEW ORLEANS (AP) — Alvin Kamara expects to be fined for wearing a pair of Christmas-themed cleats that, as it turned out, would also be worthy of a Hall of Fame display.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anthony Tommasini
title: Fanny Waterman, Doyenne of the Leeds Piano Competition, Dies at 100
description: A British pianist and teacher, she helped establish one of the world’s most important piano showcases and then presided over it for  decades.
content: Fanny Waterman, the British pianist and teacher who co-founded the prestigious Leeds International Piano Competition and oversaw it as chairwoman and artistic director for more than five decades, died on Dec. 20 at a care home in Ilkley, Yorkshire. She was 100.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryan Pietsch
title: Central and Southern California have 0 percent I.C.U. capacity, in a state already low on hospital beds.
description: California, the wealthiest and most populous state of the world’s wealthiest country, has long had a dearth of hospital beds — just 1.8 beds per 1,000 people, according to 2018 data compiled by the Kaiser Family Foundation. Now a record-shattering slew of coronavirus cases has wiped out intensive care unit capacity in a large swath of the state.
content: California, the wealthiest and most populous state of the world’s wealthiest country, has long had a dearth of hospital beds — just 1.8 beds per 1,000 people, according to 2018 data compiled by the Kaiser Family Foundation. Now a record-shattering slew of coronavirus cases has wiped out intensive care unit capacity in a large swath of the state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choire Sicha
title: Michael Alig, Fixture of New York City Nightlife, Dies at 54
description: Mr. Alig, who gained fame in the 1980s as a party promoter, was a tabloid celebrity who served 17 years in prison for manslaughter.
content: Michael Alig, a longstanding tabloid fixture of New York City and a notorious promoter of its nightlife, died on Friday at his apartment in Washington Heights. He was 54.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Jobless Benefits Run Out as Trump Resists Signing Relief Bill
description: Millions of Americans lost crucial unemployment coverage, as the president continued to criticize the bill that would keep the aid from lapsing.
content: WASHINGTON — Millions of Americans lost their unemployment coverage on Saturday as President Trump resisted signing a sweeping $900 billion aid package until lawmakers more than tripled the size of relief checks, putting the fate of the measure in limbo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang
title: She Chronicled China’s Crisis. Now She Is Accused of Spreading Lies
description: Zhang Zhan, who reported about the coronavirus from Wuhan during the lockdown, will face trial next week, in the first known case against a citizen journalist from the crisis.
content: In one video, during the lockdown in Wuhan, she filmed a hospital hallway lined with rolling beds, the patients hooked up to blue oxygen tanks. In another, she panned over a community health center, noting that a man said he was charged for a coronavirus test, even though residents believed the tests would be free.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives
title: France and Japan report cases of the virus variant that prompted lockdowns in Britain.
description: France and Japan have reported their first cases of the coronavirus variant that prompted lockdowns in Britain and is feared to be more contagious than other strains.
content: France and Japan have reported their first cases of the coronavirus variant that prompted lockdowns in Britain and is feared to be more contagious than other strains.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Fazio
title: Neverland Ranch, Former Home of Michael Jackson, Is Sold
description: Ronald W. Burkle, the billionaire co-founder of the investment firm Yucaipa Companies, bought the ranch for a reported $22 million.
content: A billionaire former associate of Michael Jackson has purchased the pop star’s former home, Neverland Ranch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charley Locke
title: Special Delivery: Thousands of Books
description: Special Delivery: Thousands of Books
content: Lily Rivera, 11, likes to invent other worlds. She lives in a setting that often inspires her: Alaska’s Adak Island, which is home to the westernmost town in the United States and has sweeping views of the Bering Sea and volcanic mountains. Another inspiration: books. “If I’m reading a book, and I’m really into it, then I can actually see the characters go and do all the things that they’re doing," Lily says.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert D. McFadden
title: George Blake, British Spy Who Betrayed the West, Dies at 98
description: He was caught spilling secrets to the Soviets in 1961 and imprisoned. Five years later, he escaped and fled to Moscow, where he was hailed as a hero.
content: George Blake, a notorious British double agent who betrayed Cold War secrets and Western spies to the Soviet Union in the 1950s and, after being caught, staged a spectacular escape to live out his life as a K.G.B. colonel in Moscow, has died. He was 98.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Giulia McDonnell Nieto del Rio
title: Nashville Explosion: What to Know
description: Federal agents were seen at a brick building on Saturday where an R.V. similar to the one that exploded had been parked in 2019.
content: Federal agents said on Saturday that they do not yet know who carried out the Christmas Day explosion that ripped through the city’s downtown, mangling storefronts, injuring three people and leaving the city mystified as to the motive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Partnerships
description: Daniel Grinberg makes his Sunday debut with a companionable puzzle.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Daniel Grinberg is one of our multisport constructors, a researcher and user experience designer who also earned a Ph.D. in film and media studies. This is only his second Times grid, and his Sunday debut, the culmination of much pandemic pondering and punnifying, if you read his notes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine J. Wu
title: Dad Got the Vaccine, but No One Else Did — Yet
description: Vaccinated health workers must navigate another new normal: households in which not all family members are immunized.
content: On the morning of Dec. 16, the threat of a Virginia snowstorm canceled school for 7-year-old Alain Bell. He instead spent the morning scribbling a scowling face in black marker onto his father’s newly vaccinated upper arm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jan Hoffman
title: Early Vaccine Doubters Now Show a Willingness to Roll Up Their Sleeves
description: Polls show that pervasive skepticism is melting, partly because of the high efficacy rates in trials and the images of real people getting the shot.
content: Ever since the race to develop a coronavirus vaccine began last spring, upbeat announcements were stalked by ominous polls: No matter how encouraging the news, growing numbers of people said they would refuse to get the shot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Renard
title: What to Watch: Wars of the Past
description: Battles at sea, in the trenches and in city streets: The movies have gone there. Here are five films that look back at the world’s conflicts.
content: Battles at sea, in the trenches and in city streets: The movies have gone there. Here are five films that look back at the world’s conflicts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Josh Katz and Kevin Quealy
title: 2020 N.F.L. Playoff Picture: Mapping the Paths That Remain for Each Team
description: Visualizing the possible outcomes with two weeks to go.
content: Visualizing the possible outcomes with two weeks to go.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press and Reuters
title: Major Truck Jam Eases at U.K. Port
description: Drivers stuck outside Port of Dover in England were tested for the coronavirus before they could cross into France. On Saturday, nearly 1,600 trucks remained in the days-long jam, down from nearly 6,000 at its peak.
content: Drivers stuck outside Port of Dover in England were tested for the coronavirus before they could cross into France. On Saturday, nearly 1,600 trucks remained in the days-long jam, down from nearly 6,000 at its peak.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Dec. 26, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Dec. 26, 2020.
content: An article on Page 4 about the online variety show “Stars in the House” misstates the date of its first livestream. It was March 16, not March 17. The article also misstates when the number of shows per week was reduced. It was in June, not May.
source.name: The New York Times
